title: Is it true that the deeper you dig on Earth or the closer you get to the center of the Earth, the stronger the pull of gravity? - Quora

response.answer_text: Couterintuitively, yes, it’s actually true - at least up to (down to?) a certain point. If you think about it, at the center of the earth, there’s zero gravity - there has to be, because there’s the same amount of matter in every direction, so you don’t get pulled in any particular direction. So you’d think that gravity would smoothly decline as you dig deeper and deeper, going from 1.0 at the surface to 0.0 at the center. And it would, if the earth were of a consistent density. But it’s not - the center parts of the earth are composed of metals, which are much denser than rocks. In fact, that’s WHY they’re at the center: they’re denser, so they sink to the “bottom” (center). So as you descend, two different things are happening: You’re getting underneath the outer layers of the earth, which will reduce the pull of gravityYou’re getting closer to the really dense stuff, which will increase the pull of gravity.Initially, the second effect dominates, and the pull of gravity goes up slightly (blue “spike” at ~3.5 below). But eventually, the first effect overwhelms the second, and the pull of gravity starts to decline again - reaching zero at the center, just as you’d expect.

To a point, but you also have to consider that the deeper you go, the more mass is actually “above” you, pulling you away from the center. There comes a point where the net force of Gravity will start going down the deeper you go. Of course this is a depth at which no human could hope to survive - air pressure would be so high the oxygen content of air would become corrosive to your lungs and the heat would literally roast your flesh.
